title: The Pooled-Risk Company Management Company
title_zh: [待翻译] The Pooled-Risk Company Management Company

paragraphs: July 2008At this year's startup school, David Heinemeier Hansson gave a talk in which he suggested that startup founders should do things the old fashioned way. Instead of hoping to get rich by building a valuable company and then selling stock in a "liquidity event," founders should start companies that make money and live off the revenues.Sounds like a good plan.

Let's think about the optimal way to do this.One disadvantage of living off the revenues of your company is that you have to keep running it. And as anyone who runs their own business can tell you, that requires your complete attention.

You can't just start a business and check out once things are going well, or they stop going well surprisingly fast.The main economic motives of startup founders seem to be freedom and security. They want enough money that (a) they don't have to worry about running out of money and (b) they can spend their time how they want.

Running your own business offers neither. You certainly don't have freedom: no boss is so demanding. Nor do you have security, because if you stop paying attention to the company, its revenues go away, and with them your income.The best case, for most people, would be if you could hire someone to manage the company for you once you'd grown it to a certain size.

Suppose you could find a really good manager. Then you would have both freedom and security. You could pay as little attention to the business as you wanted, knowing that your manager would keep things running smoothly.

And that being so, revenues would continue to flow in, so you'd have security as well.There will of course be some founders who wouldn't like that idea: the ones who like running their company so much that there's nothing else they'd rather do.

But this group must be small. The way you succeed in most businesses is to be fanatically attentive to customers' needs. What are the odds that your own desires would coincide exactly with the demands of this powerful, external force?Sure, running your own company can be fairly interesting.

Viaweb was more interesting than any job I'd had before. And since I made much more money from it, it offered the highest ratio of income to boringness of anything I'd done, by orders of magnitude. But was it the most interesting work I could imagine doing?

No.Whether the number of founders in the same position is asymptotic or merely large, there are certainly a lot of them. For them the right approach would be to hand the company over to a professional manager eventually, if they could find one who was good enough._____So far so good.

But what if your manager was hit by a bus? What you really want is a management company to run your company for you. Then you don't depend on any one person.If you own rental property, there are companies you can hire to manage it for you.

Some will do everything, from finding tenants to fixing leaks. Of course, running companies is a lot more complicated than managing rental property, but let's suppose there were management companies that could do it for you.

They'd charge a lot, but wouldn't it be worth it? I'd sacrifice a large percentage of the income for the extra peace of mind.I realize what I'm describing already sounds too good to be true, but I can think of a way to make it even more attractive.

If company management companies existed, there would be an additional service they could offer clients: they could let them insure their returns by pooling their risk. After all, even a perfect manager can't save a company when, as sometimes happens, its whole market dies, just as property managers can't save you from the building burning down.

But a company that managed a large enough number of companies could say to all its clients: we'll combine the revenues from all your companies, and pay you your proportionate share.If such management companies existed, they'd offer the maximum of freedom and security.

Someone would run your company for you, and you'd be protected even if it happened to die.Let's think about how such a management company might be organized. The simplest way would be to have a new kind of stock representing the total pool of companies they were managing.

When you signed up, you'd trade your company's stock for shares of this pool, in proportion to an estimate of your company's value that you'd both agreed upon. Then you'd automatically get your share of the returns of the whole pool.The catch is that because this kind of trade would be hard to undo, you couldn't switch management companies.

But there's a way they could fix that: suppose all the company management companies got together and agreed to allow their clients to exchange shares in all their pools. Then you could, in effect, simultaneously choose all the management companies to run yours for you, in whatever proportion you wanted, and change your mind later as often as you wanted.If such pooled-risk company management companies existed, signing up with one would seem the ideal plan for most people following the route David advocated.Good news: they do exist.

What I've just described is an acquisition by a public company._____Unfortunately, though public acquirers are structurally identical to pooled-risk company management companies, they don't think of themselves that way.

With a property management company, you can just walk in whenever you want and say "manage my rental property for me" and they'll do it. Whereas acquirers are, as of this writing, extremely fickle. Sometimes they're in a buying mood and they'll overpay enormously; other times they're not interested.

They're like property management companies run by madmen. Or more precisely, by Benjamin Graham's Mr. Market.So while on average public acquirers behave like pooled-risk company managers, you need a window of several years to get average case performance.

If you wait long enough (five years, say) you're likely to hit an up cycle where some acquirer is hot to buy you. But you can't choose when it happens.You can't assume investors will carry you for as long as you might have to wait.

Your company has to make money. Opinions are divided about how early to focus on that. Joe Kraus says you should try charging customers right away. And yet some of the most successful startups, including Google, ignored revenue at first and concentrated exclusively on development.

The answer probably depends on the type of company you're starting. I can imagine some where trying to make sales would be a good heuristic for product design, and others where it would just be a distraction.

The test is probably whether it helps you to understand your users.You can choose whichever revenue strategy you think is best for the type of company you're starting, so long as you're profitable. Being profitable ensures you'll get at least the average of the acquisition market—in which public companies do behave as pooled-risk company management companies.David isn't mistaken in saying you should start a company to live off its revenues.

The mistake is thinking this is somehow opposed to starting a company and selling it. In fact, for most people the latter is merely the optimal case of the former.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Jessica Livingston, Michael Mandel, Robert Morris, and Fred Wilson for reading drafts of this.

paragraphs.original: July 2008At this year's startup school, David Heinemeier Hansson gave a talk in which he suggested that startup founders should do things the old fashioned way. Instead of hoping to get rich by building a valuable company and then selling stock in a "liquidity event," founders should start companies that make money and live off the revenues.Sounds like a good plan.
paragraphs.translated: 2008年7月，在今年的创业学校上，David Heinemeier Hansson 发表了一次演讲，他建议创业公司创始人应该采用传统的方式。与其希望通过建立一家有价值的公司然后在“流动性事件”中出售股票来致富，创始人应该创办能够盈利的公司，并依靠这些收入生活。听起来像是个不错的计划。

paragraphs.original: Let's think about the optimal way to do this.One disadvantage of living off the revenues of your company is that you have to keep running it. And as anyone who runs their own business can tell you, that requires your complete attention.
paragraphs.translated: 让我们考虑一下最佳的处理方式。靠公司收入生活的一个缺点是，你必须继续经营这家公司。而任何经营自己生意的人都会告诉你，这需要你全心全意的投入。

paragraphs.original: You can't just start a business and check out once things are going well, or they stop going well surprisingly fast.The main economic motives of startup founders seem to be freedom and security. They want enough money that (a) they don't have to worry about running out of money and (b) they can spend their time how they want.
paragraphs.translated: 你不能在创业后，一旦事情进展顺利就撒手不管，否则情况会很快变糟。初创企业的创始人主要的经济动机似乎是自由和安全。他们希望有足够多的钱，(a) 不必担心钱会用完，(b) 可以随心所欲地支配自己的时间。

paragraphs.original: Running your own business offers neither. You certainly don't have freedom: no boss is so demanding. Nor do you have security, because if you stop paying attention to the company, its revenues go away, and with them your income.The best case, for most people, would be if you could hire someone to manage the company for you once you'd grown it to a certain size.
paragraphs.translated: 经营自己的企业两者都无法提供。你肯定没有自由：没有老板会如此苛刻。你也没有安全感，因为一旦你不再关注公司，它的收入就会消失，随之你的收入也会消失。对大多数人来说，最好的情况是，一旦公司将发展到一定规模，你可以雇用某人来管理公司。

paragraphs.original: Suppose you could find a really good manager. Then you would have both freedom and security. You could pay as little attention to the business as you wanted, knowing that your manager would keep things running smoothly.
paragraphs.translated: 假设你能找到一位非常优秀的经理。那么你将同时拥有自由和安全保障。你可以根据自己的意愿尽可能少地关注业务，因为你知道你的经理会确保一切顺利运行。

paragraphs.original: And that being so, revenues would continue to flow in, so you'd have security as well.There will of course be some founders who wouldn't like that idea: the ones who like running their company so much that there's nothing else they'd rather do.
paragraphs.translated: 如此一来，收入将继续流入，因此你也会有安全保障。当然，也会有一些创始人不喜欢这个想法：那些非常喜欢经营自己的公司，以至于没有其他事情比这更让他们乐意去做的人。

paragraphs.original: But this group must be small. The way you succeed in most businesses is to be fanatically attentive to customers' needs. What are the odds that your own desires would coincide exactly with the demands of this powerful, external force?Sure, running your own company can be fairly interesting.
paragraphs.translated: 但这个群体必须很小。在大多数企业中取得成功的方式是狂热地关注客户的需求。你的愿望与这一强大外部力量的需求完全一致的可能性有多大？当然，经营自己的公司相当有趣。

paragraphs.original: Viaweb was more interesting than any job I'd had before. And since I made much more money from it, it offered the highest ratio of income to boringness of anything I'd done, by orders of magnitude. But was it the most interesting work I could imagine doing?
paragraphs.translated: Viaweb 比我之前做的任何工作都更有趣。而且，由于从中赚的钱更多，它在收入与乏味程度的比率上远超我之前做过的任何事情，达到了几个数量级。但这是我能想象到的最有趣的工作吗？

paragraphs.original: No.Whether the number of founders in the same position is asymptotic or merely large, there are certainly a lot of them. For them the right approach would be to hand the company over to a professional manager eventually, if they could find one who was good enough._____So far so good.
paragraphs.translated: 无论是创始人数量在同一职位上趋于渐近还是仅仅庞大，确实有很多人。对于他们来说，如果能找到一个足够优秀的专业经理人，最终将公司交给这样的人来管理是正确的做法。_____到目前为止，一切顺利。

paragraphs.original: But what if your manager was hit by a bus? What you really want is a management company to run your company for you. Then you don't depend on any one person.If you own rental property, there are companies you can hire to manage it for you.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果你的经理被车撞了怎么办？你真正需要的是一家管理公司来为你运营你的公司。这样你就不会依赖任何一个人。如果你拥有出租房产，可以雇佣一些公司来为你管理。

paragraphs.original: Some will do everything, from finding tenants to fixing leaks. Of course, running companies is a lot more complicated than managing rental property, but let's suppose there were management companies that could do it for you.
paragraphs.translated: 有些人会包揽一切，从寻找租户到修理漏水。当然，经营公司要比管理出租物业复杂得多，但假设有一些管理公司可以为你代劳。

paragraphs.original: They'd charge a lot, but wouldn't it be worth it? I'd sacrifice a large percentage of the income for the extra peace of mind.I realize what I'm describing already sounds too good to be true, but I can think of a way to make it even more attractive.
paragraphs.translated: 他们会收取很多费用，但难道不值得吗？为了额外的安心，我愿意牺牲一大部分收入。我知道我描述的听起来已经好得不真实了，但我还能想到一种方法让这更加有吸引力。

paragraphs.original: If company management companies existed, there would be an additional service they could offer clients: they could let them insure their returns by pooling their risk. After all, even a perfect manager can't save a company when, as sometimes happens, its whole market dies, just as property managers can't save you from the building burning down.
paragraphs.translated: 如果存在公司管理公司，他们可以为客户提供一项额外的服务：通过风险共担让他们为收益投保。毕竟，即使是最优秀的管理者也无法在公司整个市场崩溃时拯救公司，就像物业管理公司无法在建筑被烧毁时拯救你一样。

paragraphs.original: But a company that managed a large enough number of companies could say to all its clients: we'll combine the revenues from all your companies, and pay you your proportionate share.If such management companies existed, they'd offer the maximum of freedom and security.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，如果一家公司管理着足够多的企业，它就可以对所有客户说：我们将把你们所有企业的收入汇总起来，支付给你们各自应得的份额。如果存在这样的管理公司，它们将提供最大的自由和安全保障。

paragraphs.original: Someone would run your company for you, and you'd be protected even if it happened to die.Let's think about how such a management company might be organized. The simplest way would be to have a new kind of stock representing the total pool of companies they were managing.
paragraphs.translated: 有人会为你经营你的公司，即使它不幸倒闭，你也会受到保护。让我们来思考一下这样的管理公司可能如何组织。最简单的方式是发行一种新的股票，代表他们管理的所有公司的总池。

paragraphs.original: When you signed up, you'd trade your company's stock for shares of this pool, in proportion to an estimate of your company's value that you'd both agreed upon. Then you'd automatically get your share of the returns of the whole pool.The catch is that because this kind of trade would be hard to undo, you couldn't switch management companies.
paragraphs.translated: 当你注册时，你会将你公司的股票按双方商定的你公司估值的比例，换成这个基金的股份。然后，你将自动获得整个基金回报的相应份额。但问题在于，由于这种交易很难撤销，你将无法更换管理公司。

paragraphs.original: But there's a way they could fix that: suppose all the company management companies got together and agreed to allow their clients to exchange shares in all their pools. Then you could, in effect, simultaneously choose all the management companies to run yours for you, in whatever proportion you wanted, and change your mind later as often as you wanted.If such pooled-risk company management companies existed, signing up with one would seem the ideal plan for most people following the route David advocated.Good news: they do exist.
paragraphs.translated: 但有一个解决办法：假设所有的公司管理公司聚在一起，同意让他们的客户在他们所有的基金池中交换股份。那么，你实际上可以同时选择所有的管理公司来为你管理，按照你想要的比例，并且可以随时改变主意。如果存在这样的风险共担的公司管理公司，对于遵循大卫提倡的路线的大多数人来说，加入其中一家似乎是理想的计划。好消息是：它们确实存在。

paragraphs.original: What I've just described is an acquisition by a public company._____Unfortunately, though public acquirers are structurally identical to pooled-risk company management companies, they don't think of themselves that way.
paragraphs.translated: 我刚才描述的是一家上市公司的收购。_____不幸的是，尽管上市公司在结构上与风险共担的公司管理公司相同，但他们并不这样认为。

paragraphs.original: With a property management company, you can just walk in whenever you want and say "manage my rental property for me" and they'll do it. Whereas acquirers are, as of this writing, extremely fickle. Sometimes they're in a buying mood and they'll overpay enormously; other times they're not interested.
paragraphs.translated: 有了物业管理公司，你可以随时走进去说“帮我管理我的出租房产”，他们就会照做。而买家则不同，至少在撰写本文时，他们非常善变。有时候他们购买欲望强烈，甚至愿意出高价；而有时候他们则毫无兴趣。

paragraphs.original: They're like property management companies run by madmen. Or more precisely, by Benjamin Graham's Mr. Market.So while on average public acquirers behave like pooled-risk company managers, you need a window of several years to get average case performance.
paragraphs.translated: 它们就像是由疯子经营的物业管理公司。或者更准确地说，是由本杰明·格雷厄姆的“市场先生”经营的。因此，尽管从平均水平来看，公共收购方的行为类似于风险共担的公司管理者，但你需要几年的时间窗口才能获得平均情况下的表现。

paragraphs.original: If you wait long enough (five years, say) you're likely to hit an up cycle where some acquirer is hot to buy you. But you can't choose when it happens.You can't assume investors will carry you for as long as you might have to wait.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你等待足够长的时间（比如说五年），你很可能会遇到一个上升周期，那时会有一些买家迫切想收购你。但你无法选择这一时刻何时到来。你不能假设投资者会支持你等到你可能需要的那么长时间。

paragraphs.original: Your company has to make money. Opinions are divided about how early to focus on that. Joe Kraus says you should try charging customers right away. And yet some of the most successful startups, including Google, ignored revenue at first and concentrated exclusively on development.
paragraphs.translated: 你的公司必须赚钱。关于何时开始关注这一点，意见不一。乔·克劳斯认为你应该一开始就尝试向客户收费。然而，一些最成功的初创公司，包括谷歌，在最初阶段却忽视了收入，专注于开发。

paragraphs.original: The answer probably depends on the type of company you're starting. I can imagine some where trying to make sales would be a good heuristic for product design, and others where it would just be a distraction.
paragraphs.translated: 答案可能取决于你创办的公司类型。我可以想象，在某些公司中，将销售作为产品设计的指导原则会是一个好方法，而在其他公司中，这可能会成为一种干扰。

paragraphs.original: The test is probably whether it helps you to understand your users.You can choose whichever revenue strategy you think is best for the type of company you're starting, so long as you're profitable. Being profitable ensures you'll get at least the average of the acquisition market—in which public companies do behave as pooled-risk company management companies.David isn't mistaken in saying you should start a company to live off its revenues.
paragraphs.translated: 测试的关键可能在于它是否有助于你了解你的用户。你可以选择你认为最适合你所创建公司类型的任何盈利策略，只要你是盈利的。盈利确保你至少能获得收购市场的平均水平——在这一市场中，上市公司确实像风险共担的公司管理公司那样行事。大卫说你应该创办一家公司以靠其收入生活，这是没错的。

paragraphs.original: The mistake is thinking this is somehow opposed to starting a company and selling it. In fact, for most people the latter is merely the optimal case of the former.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Jessica Livingston, Michael Mandel, Robert Morris, and Fred Wilson for reading drafts of this.
paragraphs.translated: 错误地认为这 somehow 与创办公司并出售它相对立。事实上，对大多数人来说，后者只是前者的最优情况。感谢 Trevor Blackwell、Jessica Livingston、Michael Mandel、Robert Morris 和 Fred Wilson 阅读本文的草稿。
